case_vignette: A 5-year-old female presents with a plaque on her left leg. The lesion appeared a few months after her birth. It has been increasing in size proportionally to her growth. The parents mentions that the skin lesion sometimes becomes irritated, erythematous and itchy when the patient plays with it or when she gets sick. Physical exam reveals a red-brown well delimited plaque on her left leg without any noticeable erythema or epidermal changes.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My skin lesion on my left leg sometimes gets red, irritated, and itchy, especially when I touch it a lot or when I am not feeling well.
How long have you had this lesion for?
I've had the lesion since a few months after I was born.
Does the lesion change in size or appearance over time?
Yes, the lesion has been increasing in size as I grow.
Do you have any similar lesions elsewhere on your body?
No, I don't have similar lesions anywhere else on my body.
Do you have any family members with similar skin issues or diagnosed skin conditions?
I don't know of any family members with similar skin issues or diagnosed skin conditions.
Have you received any treatments or seen a doctor for this lesion before?
I don't know if I have received any treatments or seen a doctor for this lesion before.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Melanocytic Nevus.
